title: Why is there a tendency among so many Christians to want to return to the past?

body:
Because we live in the age of meaninglessness, of idolatry, hedonism and nihilism. Ideologies that sprang up as a direct repercussion of the rejection of God killed tens of millions, and threatened to condemn humanity to extinction. Our communities are stultified, demoralised and destroyed with ever-increasing fervour by a society that has decided it no longer needs meaning, truth or beauty; only consumerism and progressivism in its stead, and whatever lies and sins are needed to eke out just a bit more short-term pleasure.  
I'm not pretending these are new vices and threats, just that before the 20th century we at least had some kind of blueprint for an answer, some organ busying itself with the question of meanng - but now we have left the church behind.

body:
-*"Actually families were pretty ruined back then, seeing as how family disowned each other over frequently, including parents disowning their children."*  This statement is almost comical.  Look at the number of single parent households today as compared to almost any other period in history.  Do fathers and sometimes mothers walking out not constitute disowning their children?  Are these not ruined families?  Trying to compare an epidemic of single parent households to rare instances of families disowning children strains credulity.  Just about every measurable data point would tell you that familial bonds were stronger in the past, not weaker.  What's the largest determining factor for a child's success?  Whether they grew up in a two-parent household.  Critique any church as you may, but I'm certain that values of familial bonds and two-parent households are a much higher priority in church than they are on social media.

-*"People back then bragged instead about their supposed piety and moral superiority, which was often actually brutality."*  What period are we talking about and, again, what can you offer to support this statement?  Not much I would imagine.  But what is wrong with celebrating shared Christian values?  It's interesting that your post has this strong undertone of fear and shaming, but you are quick to shame those who take pride in their faith and values.  

-*"People work more now and have less free time than before, another one of the few downsides to nowadays."*  Work brings meaning and purpose.  Tell the average factory worker from a hundred years ago that you work more now than they did.  We don't have less time to enjoy things.  We spend less time engaging in things that actually bring enjoyment.  

-*"Almost everyone went to church as not to fear ostracization and even punishment, not out of heart."*  This is nonsense.  Churches functioned as the central hub of communities.  They brought people together.  They fostered support for one another.  They helped people when they were in need.  What does that look like today?  Instead of a handshake or a hug on Sunday we click a like button on social media.  Instead of rallying around a sick member in the community we click a button to give them $20 to a gofundme without ever seeing their face.  As church fades away  consumerism and social media have moved in to fill the void.  Are we really in a better place?  

-*"And this church did not represent actual Christianity at all; it instead taught the doctrines of the pharisees: legalism, mercilessness, fear, ruthlessness, unforgiveness, conformity to the world, and hatred."*  Again, this depends on who and when.  There are, without a doubt, instances of this within the "church" (looking at you, Catholicism).  But I think any statement that attempts to cast this wide of a net across a concept (church) is very shortsighted.  And again, placing your statement within the context of now versus then, "legalism, mercilessness, fear, ruthlessness, unforgiveness, conformity to the world and hatred' all seem to be the flavors of the day.  If you look around today and see progress then I'm at a loss for words.

> This statement is almost comical. Look at the number of single parent households today as compared to almost any other period in history.
